text: Hey sentdex, I managed to train the model much faster by increasing the batch size from 128 to 2048 on my 1080Ti (3hrs vs 40mins). Hope this helps!

author: @MackTheTemp1
text: I think your model could be improved by providing an elementary training set where the training data only has ints 0-100. Given that you're trying to train the neural net to 'learn math' consider that humans have seperate neural processes for estimating the multiplication / addition of numbers and actually calculating them. They they take different amounts of energey/time for our brains and are located in different areas of the brain -- Thinking Fast and Slow.  I believe there are axiomatic first principles of math that the bot will never imagine if it's trying to guess what the product of two huge numbers is in a nano second before checking it's reward status. If you think about the data we consume when learning math, it's highly curated.

author: @Eurley66
text: What if you trained the model on increasingly complex data -- That is to say, begin with 1 char numbers, then 2, etc. up to 5. Maybe the model would learn the operations? I'm also curious to know if families of neurons activate given a specific operation or order of operations. What if the loss function the model was trying to minimize was an absolute difference function instead of a least squares one? So much questions flow when dealing with these! I'll try and do some research with my own models with basic mathematics, it feels like digging and getting more and more comprehension of the models doing so. Anyway, very impressive to see the model get so close results, given how big the numbers are.

author: @Iwantyoudie1995
text: I'm wondering if we could use the difference between the expected output number and the output of the network (treated as a float) as the loss function used in training. I mean, I'm guessing that the model is using some sort of character-wise loss function (I didn't study this model), but probably a loss function that takes in account the real purpose that is to minimize the difference can help.  However i'm not an expert, it was more a doubt than an advice.

author: @_jelle
text: You're asking it to predict 17 digit numbers, maybe you should just let it predict the 8 or so most significant digits to give it more of a chance. Something of the form 1.2345678e+9 instead of 1234567801.23456789. I also think the fact that it's training just as hard on the 17th digit as it does on the 1st digit might be a problem, that could just be adding noise to your training because it's never going to learn to get the 17th digit right anyway.

author: @danweecc
text: I'm wondering what would happen if you gave it a problem with numbers bigger than it trained for. Will it be able to infer the rules and go from there?
